body:
It's not a problem of having thousands of files in the queue, we perform batching based on reads in the database. I think this a dup of https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/1434
With a relation to the expensive `withNeed` calls.
another probably related issue is that CPU is alway 99% when there is so large list of files

BTW it is problem for me to have thousands of files in a queue, especially because they don't have to be there if st was smarter it would be matter of few minutes to get rid of all small files, that each take seconds to sync, making the queue small.
or perhaps if scheduler worked in paralel, and synced smallest files in separate thread it would work as well, this way the large files would never freeze syncing for long time

I don't think the queue has anything to do with this. The queue is just a list of strings, and I think having 250000 strings is perfectly fine to fit in RAM and shouldn't cause CPU load.

The queue is there specifically so that you could prioritize files which you want yourself.
Otherwise, if we didn't allow you to make any decisions, there wouldn't be a queue.

Sending smaller files first is not necessarily always the right answer, there is a large fixed amount of work associated with finalizing receiving a file, hence syncing one large file is more efficient than 250000 small files, as for every file we have to update the database (which is probably where the load comes from).

You might want to increase the number of copiers and pullers in the config which should help syncthing to plow through the queue quicker as by default it deals with a single file at a time, making up to 16 concurrent requests per file.

Currently there are so many files in the queue that I can't even display it
in GUI, so I can't really order it nor see why syncing is stuck. I don't
even know if it works at all, I occasionally watch the progress doing find
folder | wc -l and watching how number of files increases, but IMHO it's
much slower than it should be. Sometimes the number even stuck for like 40
minutes and then some more files are added. I don't know why is that, I
can't see in GUI what is going on.

On Sun, Mar 22, 2015 at 3:54 PM, Audrius Butkevicius <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I don't think the queue has anything to do with this. The queue is just a
> list of strings, and I think having 250000 strings is perfectly fine to fit
> in RAM and shouldn't cause CPU load.
> 
> The queue is there specifically so that you could prioritize files which
> you want yourself.
> 
> Sending smaller files first is not necessarily always the right answer,
> there is a large fixed amount of work associated with finalizing receiving
> a file, hence syncing one large file is more efficient than 250000 small
> files, as for every file we have to update the database (which is probably
> where the load comes from).
> 
> You might want to increase the number of copiers and pullers in the config
> which should help syncthing to plow through the queue quicker.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/1509#issuecomment-84625358
> .
What I hate most is that I have to restart the program with every little change to configs, which results in syncig getting stuck for another hour needed to gt the list of files that ren't snced

We currently have an issue with the GUI calls that consume too much CPU&IO. Please close the GUI if you run into performance issues and let the sync finish first. Afterwards the GUI should be less cpu/io intensive.

I feel this is fixed by https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/commit/454e688c3d626f8e2413d8c0d8acc65c204d8981

Try the beta, and reopen if it's still an issue.
Reopening due to the other issue described here.

rename.to: Add pagination to `Out of sync` list

body:
Thanks for pointing it out.

Previously it was just a list of 100 items which was just long (hence we could live with it), now it's potentially a list of 1 million items which causes the browser to lock up.

Hence this one is more important and that one is now a duplicate in some sense.

issue.title: Fix the "out of sync items" modal

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New features or improvements of some kind, as opposed to a problem (bug)

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Good starting points for new contributors

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
- It shouldn't be much longer than the screen. Scroll instead.
- Long filenames shouldn't screw it up.
- It should be keyboard closable. (#508, #498)

body:
The problem is that there is just no way to display all items that are out
of sync, even when I do REST thing I only see small portion of files, while
GUI shows thosands of files that aren't synced (while telling me that
syncing was finished) so I assume that these thousands of files are
actually ignored. I think that whole list of unsynced items need to be
split to multiple lists:
- Files queued to be synced
- Files that are being synced
- Files that are not going to be synced

All these 3 lists should be expandable

On Tue, Apr 7, 2015 at 7:06 PM, Audrius Butkevicius <
notifications@github.com> wrote:
